g.text: The testis, frozen 10–12 h after death, was obtained from the
PA, USA) from a donor free of drug treatments that interfere
with normal spermatogenesis. The sample was collected from
an anonymous organ donor and complied with the ethical regu-
lations for collection of human samples approved by the Institu-
tional Review Board of the University of Southern California
and certiﬁed as exempt (46.101 b4). Testis dissection and
DNA isolation was performed as published (
The number of ampliﬁable genomes in the DNA from each
testis piece was determined by real-time PCR using primers
g of ampliﬁable DNA from each individual testis
piece was pre-ampliﬁed for 20 cycles, which served as template
DNA for the subsequent steps of emulsion PCR (BEA). Each
Phusion Hot start DNA polymerase (NEB) and 0.2
primer F-ACH-88 and R-SNP. The reactions were held at
C for 2 min followed by 20 cycles of 98
C for 30 s and a ﬁnal extension step at 72
This procedure follows exactly the protocols described previ-
ously with small differences in the primers and PCR conditions
l of a 1:100 or 1:500 dilution of
with the dual biotinylated primer R-ACH-bead primer (MWG/
. The last 20 bp of this primer are complementary
end of the pre-BEA PCR product. Hybridizations were
cooling down to room temperature. The beads were washed
once with water and mixed with the aqueous PCR phase (1
pared by vortexing at full speed for 70 s with a 5 mm steel
bead (Qiagen) and ampliﬁed by an initial denaturation step of
C for 2 min, followed by 55 cycles at 94
C for 75 s with an end step of at 68
were washed and labeled as described previously (
G) probes using an initial denaturation step of 95
C to wash off unextended probes (asterisks denote
a product given the low input ratio of DNA molecules to beads
assuring that most of the beads get attached to only one initial
molecule based on Poisson distribution. Experiments with
30% positives were discarded and repeated, considering that
beads seeded with more than one molecule could result in an
underestimate of the mutation number. Of the 192 pieces, the
125 000 beads with a product. Any multicolored bead reﬂects
the presence of both mutant and wild-type molecules due to
mutations during the BEA and therefore was eliminated
After scanning the beads with a microscope as described previ-
), the probes were washed off and new probes with
G) were used to re-label the beads at
C to wash off unextended probes. The dye
switch was performed in a hybridization chamber and
immobilized on a polyacrylamide array, it was possible to
re-scan the beads without losing the positional information of
For each experiment two sets with three images each were ana-
lyzed. Brightﬁeld images between scans (normal scan and dye
switch scan) were aligned by computing the normalized cross-
correlation matrix of pairs of images in Matlab (Mathworks)
bination of both bright ﬁelds was employed to extract the inten-
sity values for deﬁned regions of interests (ROI) representing
each bead across the ﬂuorescent channels (two per scan). The
average pixel intensities for each ROI was compiled for each
ﬂuorescent channel to classify the beads into different clusters
(10, 01, 11, 00) based on the signal intensity for each ﬂuorophore
(the 11 cluster represents beads ﬂuorescing in both channels and
the 00 cluster represents empty beads with no ﬂuorescence). The
classiﬁcation scheme was based on a Gaussian Mixture model
and normalization parameters were described in detail previous-
). Beads classiﬁed as 1001 were counted as wild type and
For experiments used to determine the false-positive mutation
330 000 copies (equivalent to the amount of FGFR3 copies
g of human DNA) of a linearized plasmid with a
550 bp FGFR3 insert containing the wild-type c.1138 locus
and ampliﬁed by ‘pre-BEA PCR’ (using the same conditions
g of genomic testis DNA). A dilution was
further analyzed with BEA as described earlier. The plasmid
was constructed by cloning a PCR product derived from blood
genomic DNA ampliﬁed for 35 cycles using the ‘Pre-BEA
PCR’ conditions into a pJET1.2/blunt Cloning Vector
